instruction: What is the relationship between settler colonialism and the labor aristocracy?
response: Settler colonialism and labor aristocracy are intrinsically linked. Settler colonialism is fundamentally about land ownership - eradicating Indigenous peoples through genocide and displacement so settlers can occupy, 'improve,' and capitalize emptied land. In exchange for settling labor and participating in Indigenous elimination, settlers receive land slices as reward. Home ownership - extending to 65.6% of Americans including nearly 50% of Black Americans - represents this transfer's modern form. The mortgage transforms housing from use-value into financialized commodity, the vector through which settler colonialism bestows spoils. Prior to abolition, enslaved Black people harvested cotton refined by settler workers into garments creating good-paying jobs that bourgeoisified the proletariat - Engels observed this in 1858. After abolition, sharecropping continued extraction. Internal colonies today - Navajo uranium, Palestinian olives - face the same dynamics. Though settler colonialism's US process is most mature globally, it is never complete: Indigenous nations still exist and actively resist. Standing Rock, Hawaiian water contamination, Navajo uranium struggles are contemporary examples. Settler colonialism provides the territorial and material foundation upon which labor aristocracy rests.

source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How does settler-colonialism function as an ongoing process rather than a historical event?
response: Marxist analysis emphasizes: 'settler colonialism is not a single event, but rather a continuous process of displacement, extermination, and theft.' This corrects a common liberal error: 'Often times, liberals and even some socialists will say something along the lines of "Settler colonialism was definitely a problem, but that's all in the past now. It's over, and the settlers are here to stay." This is both extremely racist against Indigenous people, as well as factually incorrect.' Evidence for ongoing settler-colonialism includes 'Al-Aqsa Flood on October 7th, 2023' which demonstrates 'the genocidal process of settler colonialism is an ongoing thing.' In the United States, contemporary examples include 'the poisoning of the Hawaiian nations water supply and the building of oil pipelines through Standing Rock Sioux territory.' Settler-colonialism 'never finishes or completes. It only varies in degrees of maturity of the process. The United States can be said to be the most mature settler colony in world history.' This analysis matters because it reveals that Indigenous resistance - whether Palestinian or Native American - isn't responding to past grievances but to ongoing displacement and genocide. The struggle is not historical but present.

instruction: What is the materialist explanation for why settler-colonialism is inherently genocidal?
response: Marxist analysis provides a rigorous materialist analysis: 'settler colonialism is always, in every single form, an inherently genocidal philosophy. On a theoretical and material level, when we set aside all of the ideological window dressing, Settler Colonialism is about the appropriation of land from an Indigenous nation(s) into the control of a population of settlers.' The mechanism is necessarily eliminationist: 'The method by which this is done, is through the eradication and genocide of the Indigenous population who are replaced with a settler population.' This isn't incidental cruelty but structural necessity - the land cannot be settled while Indigenous people occupy it. This analysis identifies the class bargain underlying settler-colonialism: 'The settlers, coming from all types of class backgrounds to include the working class, are offered a bargain by the imperialist bourgeoisie. In exchange for their service as settlers clearing the land of the Indigenous people and bringing the land into the relations of capitalist production, the settlers would be given a small chunk of that land to claim as their own.' This explains settler behavior materially: 'This material dynamic of exchanging land for genocidal services is the foundational bargain upon which settler colonialism is founded.' The genocide isn't excessive or aberrant - it's the entire point.

instruction: According to Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz, what is the fundamental nature of the United States as a political formation?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz argues that to say the United States is a colonialist settler-state is not to make an accusation but rather to face historical reality, without which not much in US history makes sense unless Indigenous peoples are erased. Under the crust of the United States are interred the bones, villages, fields, and sacred objects of American Indians. Settler colonialism is inherently genocidal in terms of the genocide convention—entailing torture, terror, sexual abuse, massacres, systematic military occupations, removals of Indigenous peoples from their ancestral territories, and removals of Indigenous children to military-like boarding schools. The absence of even the slightest note of regret or tragedy in the annual celebration of US independence betrays a deep disconnect in the consciousness of US Americans.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How does Dunbar-Ortiz challenge the 'myth of the pristine wilderness' in North America?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz explains that with the onset of colonialism, control of the land was wrenched away from Indigenous peoples, and the forests grew dense so that later European settlers were unaware of the former cultivation, sculpting, and manicuring of the landscape. Abandoned fields of corn turned to weeds and bushes. Settlers chopped down trees in New England until the landscape was nearly bare. As one geographer notes, 'Paradoxical as it may seem, there was undoubtedly much more forest primeval in 1850 than in 1650.' Anglo-Americans who did observe Native habitat management in action misunderstood what they saw. The 'wilderness' was not pristine but had been carefully managed by Indigenous peoples for millennia before colonization disrupted these practices.

source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What was the relationship between Indigenous governance systems and the US Constitution according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that Indigenous governance varied widely in form. East of the Mississippi River, towns and federations of towns were governed by family lineages. The male elder of the most powerful clan was the executive, but his accession to that position and all his decisions were subject to the approval of a council of elders of the clans represented in the town. The Haudenosaunee people today retain a fully functioning government of this type. It was the Haudenosaunee constitution, called the Great Law of Peace, that inspired essential elements of the US Constitution. This challenges the Eurocentric narrative that democratic governance was a European invention brought to the Americas.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How did English colonists at Jamestown relate to Indigenous peoples according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that the first Jamestown settlers lacked a supply line and proved unable or unwilling to grow crops or hunt for their own sustenance. They decided they would force the farmers of the Powhatan Confederacy—some thirty polities—to provide them with food. Military leader John Smith threatened to kill all the women and children if the Powhatan leaders would not feed and clothe the settlers as well as provide them with land and labor. The leader Wahunsonacock entreated: 'Why should you take by force that from us which you can have by love? Why should you destroy us, who have provided you with food? What can you get by war?' Smith's threat was carried out—total war against the Indigenous population became the colonial pattern from the beginning.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What was the scale of destruction during the Revolutionary War against Cherokee towns?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that during the Revolutionary War, more than a thousand Cherokee homes were laid waste, and some fifty thousand bushels of corn and other provisions were either burned or looted. The Virginia and North Carolina separatist authorities pooled their manpower and organized a force that effected a broad sweep of annihilation through Cherokee towns, driving residents into present-day middle Tennessee and northern Alabama, where they exterminated Indigenous families and burned down the towns in that area too. Throughout the war between separatist settlers and the monarchy, armed settlers waged total war against Indigenous people, largely realizing their objectives. The Cherokees were forced to accept tributary status, yet the attacks continued.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How does Dunbar-Ortiz analyze Andrew Jackson's role in Indigenous genocide?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz argues that it's not that Jackson had a 'dark side,' as his apologists rationalize and which all human beings have, but rather that Jackson was the Dark Knight in the founding mythology of the United States. The fledgling US government's method of dealing with Native people—a process which included systematic genocide, property theft, and total subjugation—reached its nadir in 1830 under Jackson's federal policy. More than any other president, he used forcible removal to expel the eastern tribes from their land. After the Battle of Horseshoe Bend, Jackson's troops fashioned reins for their horses' bridles from skin stripped from Muskogee bodies and distributed souvenirs from the corpses 'to the ladies of Tennessee.'

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What was the role of an Indigenous 'comprador class' in colonization according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz explains that through British and US colonization of the Muskogee Nation and other southeastern Indigenous nations, an Indigenous client class—called 'compradors' by Africans, 'caciques' in Spanish-colonized America—essential to colonialist projects was firmly in place. This privileged class was dependent on their colonial masters for their personal wealth. This class division wracked the traditional relatively egalitarian and democratic Indigenous societies internally. This small elite in the Southeast embraced the enslavement of Africans, and a few even became affluent planters through intermarriage with Anglos. The trading posts established by US merchants further divided Indigenous society, pulling many into dependency and debt.

source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How did Indigenous peoples use Mexico as refuge from US colonialism?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that during the first decade of Mexican independence, some ten thousand Cherokees, Seminoles, Shawnees, and many other Indigenous communities east of the Mississippi avoided forced removal to Indian Territory and escaped the iron heel of the United States by taking refuge in Mexico. One such community was the Coahuila Kikapú (Kickapoo) Nation, forced out of its homeland when Wisconsin was opened for settlement. The Tohono O'odam Nation did not move anywhere, but the redrawn 1848 border split their homeland. The independent Republic of Mexico provided land grants for various Indigenous communities, offering sanctuary from US genocide.

instruction: What happened to Indigenous treaty rights in 1871 according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz explains that the 371 treaties between Indigenous nations and the United States were all promulgated during the first century of US existence. Congress halted formal treaty making in 1871 by attaching a rider to the Indian Appropriation Act stipulating 'that hereafter no Indian nation or tribe within the territory of the United States shall be acknowledged or recognized as an independent nation, tribe, or power with whom the United States may contract by treaty.' This unilateral declaration ended recognition of Indigenous sovereignty while the US continued to violate the treaties it had already signed.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How did General Sherman justify genocide against Indigenous peoples?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that three weeks before the Wounded Knee massacre, General Sherman made clear he regretted nothing of his three decades of carrying out genocide. In a press conference in New York City, he said, 'Injins must either work or starve. They never have worked; they won't work now, and they will never work.' When a reporter asked, 'But should not the government supply them with enough to keep them from starvation?' Sherman replied, 'Why should the government support 260,000 able-bodied campers? No government that the world has ever seen has done such a thing.' This explicitly genocidal reasoning justified the deliberate starvation of Indigenous peoples.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What was the Indian Claims Commission and why was it inadequate according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz explains that in 1946 Congress established the Indian Claims Commission and the Indian Claims Court to legitimize the prior illegal federal taking of Indigenous treaty lands. Between 1946 and 1952—the cutoff date for filing claims—370 petitions representing 850 claims were filed on behalf of Indigenous nations. Although the government's stated purpose was to clear title for lands illegally taken, the claims mechanism barred restitution of lands taken illegally or acquiring new ones to replace the loss. Settlement was limited to monetary compensation based on the property's value at the time of taking—not current value—making it a tool for legitimizing theft rather than providing justice.

source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How were precedents from Indigenous genocide used in the War on Terror?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz documents that in 2011, a Pentagon lawyer argued to uphold the conviction of a Guantánamo detainee by citing an 1818 tribunal precedent. In his brief, the lawyer wrote: 'Not only was the Seminole belligerency unlawful, but, much like modern-day al Qaeda, the very way in which the Seminoles waged war against U.S. targets itself violate the customs and usages of war.' The Center for Constitutional Rights objected to this passage, highlighting how legal frameworks developed to criminalize Indigenous resistance continue to be deployed against those designated as enemies of the US empire.

instruction: How does Dunbar-Ortiz connect the Indian wars to US overseas imperialism?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz traces direct personnel continuity between Indigenous genocide and overseas empire. General Miles, who led the army's pursuit of Chief Joseph and the Nez Perce and commanded five thousand soldiers to capture Geronimo, in 1898 personally commanded the forces that seized Puerto Rico. His second in command, General Wesley Merritt, who had served under Custer fighting Sioux and Cheyenne resistance, was assigned to head the military invasion of the Philippines. General Henry Lawton, to whom Geronimo had surrendered, commanded the army occupation of the Philippines. The same officers who perfected genocidal warfare against Indigenous peoples immediately applied those methods to colonize overseas territories.

instruction: What does the Winchester Mystery House symbolize according to Dunbar-Ortiz?
response: Dunbar-Ortiz uses the Winchester Mystery House as an allegory for settler-colonial consciousness. The widow of the Winchester rifle heir spent decades having construction workers build every day from dawn to dusk, adding rooms with stairways that dead-end, secret trapdoors, closet doors that open to walls, and pieces of furniture that are really doors. Visitors are astounded by the evidence of the fears and anguish of an obviously mentally disturbed person. Yet Dunbar-Ortiz suggests there is another interpretation: the house represents the elaborate psychological mechanisms settlers construct to avoid confronting the genocide upon which their wealth and nation are built—endless additions and false passages that lead nowhere, designed to evade accountability.

instruction: What is the purpose of the book 'All the Real Indians Died Off' by Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz and Dina Gilio-Whitaker?
response: The book systematically debunks common myths about Native Americans that have been woven into history books by predominantly non-Native historians who have wittingly or unwittingly served political agendas. The authors note that there has been a marked shift in how history is being told, thanks to increasing scholarship by Native peoples and their allies who have been reframing conventional historical narratives through postcolonial theory. This reframing recognizes the role of imperial and state power—and its abuse—in shaping the modern world, viewing history in terms of post-Columbus European and US expansionism and its ongoing effects on Indigenous people.

source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How do Dunbar-Ortiz and Gilio-Whitaker challenge the Bering Strait theory?
response: The authors argue that the Bering Strait theory is an increasingly slippery slope that can at best be thought of as only one among numerous possible scenarios for the peopling of the Americas. Even the National Park Service acknowledges uncertainty, noting that while genetic findings suggest migration from southern Siberia as early as 30,000 years ago with crossing to the Americas by 16,500 years ago, this may represent the earliest migration but was not the only one. The theory has deep roots in Christian theology and is connected to scientific racism and manifest destiny—serving to delegitimize Indigenous claims to being original peoples of the Americas.

source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What is 'scientific racism' in relation to Native Americans according to Dunbar-Ortiz and Gilio-Whitaker?
response: Scientific racism has deep roots in Christian theology and is connected to manifest destiny. Manifest destiny was first articulated as the guiding principle for US expansionism, underpinned by Euro-American ethnocentrism and the imperative of Christian fundamentalists to save the Indian soul. The 'white man's burden' was based on a deeply entrenched ideology of the racial inferiority of nonwhite peoples, which by the 1880s had been shored up by evolving social Darwinist theories. The authors trace how non-Natives' obsession with defining Indians was critiqued by scholars like Vine Deloria Jr. and Robert Berkhofer, who exposed this history of using pseudo-science to justify dispossession and genocide.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: How do Dunbar-Ortiz and Gilio-Whitaker explain Indigenous peoples' resistance to participating in genetic research?
response: The authors argue that few people in the world have more reason to be anti-science than American Indians, given the history of how science was used in service of US political agendas to dispossess them of their lands and subjugate them. When non-Native researchers complain about Native Americans refusing to participate in genetic studies, dismissing this as 'petty identity politics contra science,' they ignore this legitimate historical distrust. The legacy of scientific racism—using pseudo-scientific theories to justify dispossession, forced assimilation, and genocide—means Indigenous communities have well-founded reasons to be skeptical of research conducted by outsiders who have historically used 'science' as a weapon against them.

source.article_title: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States
source.author: Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz
source.work: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

instruction: What do Dunbar-Ortiz and Gilio-Whitaker say about the 'Indians don't pay taxes' myth?
response: The authors explain that while Indian nations' tribal gaming enterprises are not subject to federal income tax, income derived from gaming and distributed in per capita payments to individuals IS taxed. Despite laws precluding taxation of revenues from Indian trust lands, the IRS for years aggressively attempted to collect taxes, leading to a crisis in 2012 with congressional hearings. Harassment and intimidation tactics against the Oglala Sioux at Pine Ridge included IRS agents showing up unannounced demanding records for everything from powwow prize money to health-care benefits. When tribal members protested this as a violation of treaty rights, one was told by an IRS agent, 'You can read your treaties in prison, if you like.'
